home_page.welcome: Welcome to the Nanliao Community Guide App
home_page.description: This app is designed for the Nanliao community and provides multiple guide features for visitors.

target_focus.menu: You can scroll here to view more attractions!

qr_page.title: QR Code Scanner
qr_page.scan_instruction: Point the camera at a QR Code to scan

page1.title: Fuji Fish Steaming House
page1.content: Built in 1959 by Dai Fuji, the traditional fish steaming house includes a stove area, chimney, and brine tank. During summer sardine season, fishermen steamed and dried fish here for export to Taiwan and Japan. In 2012, the community restored the site to preserve its historical appearance.

page2.title: Small Farmers' Market
page2.content: Nanliao has long been a farming village, producing seasonal crops such as corn, peanuts, sweet potatoes, pumpkins, and vegetables. In 2014, villagers worked together to renovate an abandoned space and turned it into a spot for occasional farmers' markets promoting fresh produce and eco-friendly concepts.

page3.title: Xu Fan Old House
page3.content: Built between 1851‚Äì1861, the house features traditional Penghu stone structures. Renovated in 1935 by Xu Fan, a Taoist practitioner, it is now registered as a historic building due to its cultural and religious value.

page4.title: Coral Stone Tree House
page4.content: This old house once included a pharmacy, private school, and barbershop. In 2013, international volunteers helped restore the site, transforming it into a unique historical attraction.

page5.title: Floating Buoy Art Zone
page5.content: Nanliao often receives large amounts of ocean debris due to northeast monsoon winds. A retired local resident began collecting buoy waste and transformed it into an environmental art space.

page6.title: Zhao Family Old Houses
page6.content: Located between No. 77 and No. 95 of Nanliao, these houses retain a classic Penghu style. After community cleaning and restoration, the peaceful alley reflects the charm of old island life.

page7.title: Cow Dung Pit
page7.content: Restored in 2013, this area recreates traditional farming life such as cow dung processing. It now serves as an environmental education site.

page8.title: One-Day Farmer
page8.content: Nanliao has vast farmlands surrounding the village. Visitors can imagine traditional farming scenes‚Äîplowing fields, stacking coral stones, picking crops‚Äîand experience the warmth and vitality of the land.

page9.title: Masked Ladies
page9.content: Penghu women traditionally wore cloth wraps to protect themselves from sun, cold winds, and sea spray. This unique style is now listed as an intangible cultural heritage.

page10.title: Coral Stone Walls
page10.content: These walls are built from coral stones collected during low tide and transported by boat. After years of weathering, the stones were used to construct houses and windbreaks. Today, coral harvesting is prohibited to preserve marine ecosystems.

page11.title: Zhao Ancestral Temple
page11.content: Used as a military camp in 1949, the site once hosted gatherings, performances, and open-air movies. After the military left, it became a lively fish steaming area. Today it serves as the ancestral shrine for the Zhao family.

page12.title: Experience Farm
page12.content: Run by Zhao Jia-Xie, the farm practices organic and eco-friendly farming. Certified organic in 2014, it offers tours and hands-on activities promoting sustainable agriculture.

page13.title: Rice Dough Animal Park
page13.content: In the past, Penghu families made small rice dough animal figures during festivals as offerings for blessings. This park was built to preserve and showcase this local cultural tradition.
